projectDesc.p: "The Song of Heinrich" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.
Abbreviations in the Old High German text are expanded, spelling and punctuation otherwise follow the manuscript.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: De Heinrico
app.rdg: The Song of Heinrich

app.lem: Nunc almus assis filius thero euuigero thiernun
app.rdg: Now help, kind son of the eternal Virgin,

app.lem: benignus fautor mihi, thaz ig iz cosan muozi
app.rdg: be my benevolent protector, so that I may tell of

app.lem: de quodam duce, themo heron Heinriche,
app.rdg: a certain duke, of Lord Heinrich.

app.lem: qui cum dignitate thero Beiaro riche beuuarode.
app.rdg: who governed the realm of Bavaria with honor

app.lem: Intrans nempe nuntius, then keisar namoda her thus:
app.rdg: Once there came a herald, who addressed the emperor thus:

app.lem: ›cur sedes‹ infit ›Otdo. ther unsar keisar guodo
app.rdg: “Why are you, our good emperor Otto, still sitting?” he asked.

app.lem: hic adest Heinrich bringit her hera kuniglich.
app.rdg: “Heinrich is here, he brings a kingly entourage

app.lem: dignum tibi fore thir seluemo ze sine.‹
app.rdg: that would be worthy of being your own.”

app.lem: Tunc surrexit Otdo, ther unsar keisar guodo,
app.rdg: Then Otto stood up, our good emperor,

app.lem: perrexit illi obuiam inde uilo manig man.
app.rdg: and went towards him [Heinrich] together with many men

app.lem: et excepit illum mid mihilon eron.
app.rdg: And he greeted him [Heinrich] with great honor

app.lem: Primitus quoque dixit: ›uuillicumo Heinrich,
app.rdg: First he said: “Welcome, Heinrich,

app.lem: ambo uos equiuoci, bethiu goda endi mi:
app.rdg: to both of you with the same name, from both God and me.

app.lem: nec non et socii, uuillicumo sid gi mi.‹
app.rdg: And to your companions, too: you are welcome here.” Literally: 'you are welcome to me'.

app.lem: Dato responso fane Heinriche so scono
app.rdg: After the greeting was returned in kind by Heinrich,

app.lem: coniunxere manus. her leida ina in thaz godes hus:
app.rdg: they took each other by the hand. He [Otto] lead him to the church:

app.lem: petierunt ambo thero godes genatheno.
app.rdg: both sought the grace of God.

app.lem: Oramine facto intfieng ina auer Otdo,
app.rdg: After the prayer he [Heinrich] greeted Otto again

app.lem: duxit in concilium mit michelon eron
app.rdg: And he lead him [Heinrich] with great honor to the council

app.lem: et admisit illi so uuaz so her þar hafode,
app.rdg: And granted him everything that he had at his disposal,

app.lem: preter quod regale, thes thir Heinrih ni gerade.
app.rdg: except kingly rights, which Heinrich never coveted.

app.lem: Tunc stetit al thiu sprakha sub firmo Heinriche:
app.rdg: So thereafter all counseling was under Heinrich’s stewardship.

app.lem: quicquid Otdo fecit, al geried iz Heinrih:
app.rdg: Whatever Otto did, he conferred about it with Heinrich.

app.lem: quicquid ac omisit, ouch geried iz Heinrihc.
app.rdg: And whatever Otto did not do, he conferred about it with Heinrich, too.

app.lem: Hic non fuit ullus – thes hafon ig guoda fulleist
app.rdg: There was no one – this I have on good authority –

app.lem: nobilibus ac liberis, thaz thid allaz uuar is –
app.rdg: neither nobleman nor freeman – this is the complete truth –

app.lem: cui non fecisset Heinrich allero rehto gilich.
app.rdg: to whom Heinrich would not have granted all rights.
